ul_524395: $> fn(){DATA=$(sed -n ''"$2"'p' $1 | trans -no-init -no-warn -b -t ru) && \
sed -i ''"$2"'a '"$DATA"'' $1} && \
fn file_for_transalate.md 82

Explanations about Options.-no-warn: Do not write warning messages to stderr.
Explanations about Options.-t:
Specify the target language(s) (the language(s) of translated text). When
 specifying two or more language codes, concatenate them by plus sign "+".

Top-3 Similar Questions: su_1018824: How to temporarily change the gateway of a secondary IP?
so_31412006: how do you translate this ssh command into a ssh_config file?

Explanations about Options.-N: Do not execute a remote command. This is useful for just forwarding ports.
Explanations about Options.-f:
Requests ssh to go to background just before command execution. This is useful if
 ssh is going to ask for passwords or passphrases, but the user wants it in the
 background. This implies -n. The recommended way to start X11 programs at a remote
 site is with something like ssh -f host xterm.
